column4: If I install a program with apt-get, where is it supposed to be available in the newest version of Ubuntu?
I am trying to find the executable for cree.py: http://ilektrojohn.github.com/creepy/.
source at https://github.com/ilektrojohn/creepy
Try "whereis $program_name".
That's a python file, which is not a binary.
You have to be in the same directory as cree.py.

cree.py is, as I recall, a graphical program. I remember checking it out to teach my grade school kids about internet stalkers.  Anyway, do you notice a graphical window popping up **underneath** your console window?
It is a graphical program, yes. But nothing happens.
Got an idea.
You're running this with sudo, right?
Try this: DISPLAY=:0 python ./cree.py
Pardon: DISPLAY=:0 sudo python ./cree.py
Nothing happens. By the look of it.
Try switching the order of display and sudo, ie: sudo DISPLAY=:0 python ./cree.py
Ok. I have another idea. Give me a second to make sure I get the command right ...
Thanks. Appreciate it.
Ok. Hit Alt-F2. Type "gksudo". A window should pop up. Type "python /path/to/dir/cree.py".
Ooops. It's Alt-F2. Type "gksudo python /path/to/dir/cree.py". Then type your passwd in the next window.
not sure what you mean there.
I am suddenly in a DOS-like interface
Oh. You must have hit Ctrl-Alt-F2 instead of just Alt-F2.
Hit Alt-F7 to get back.
Ok. Well, I'm spent on ideas, then. Sorry.
